item.title: [REPL-102] [IoC] Map Type Dependencies on Container
item.description:
Multiplexer Dependency Setup (container/DI)

Configure component lifecycle and resolution for generic repositories (e.g.: common.Searchable[replay_entity.Badge] as BadgeReader ) for resolving dependencies of the core search component SearchableResourceMultiplexer (“Dictionary” implementation for routing resources to it’s corresponding SearchController[T any] instance)

Architectural Instructions:

IOC:
As ReplayAPI applies loose coupling, we’ve set up a dedicated module for dependency injection under /src/pkg/infra/ioc

Hexagonal Architecture (Ports And Adapters):
ReplayAPI is designed to work with inbound ports ("driving” adapters, or entry points, such as MobileApp, API or CommandLine Interface) and outbound ports (“driven”adapters, such as repositories or clients to third-party services or external data).

A Searchable is an interface of Outbound Port (or Output Port, which is the same but appears in some references with this alternative naming).

A Port is an interface with very small granularity.
An Adapter (in the context of “Ports and Adapters”) is the concrete implementation of a Port.

In the case of common.Searchable[replay_entity.Badge], it represents a interface definition of a Driven component (an Outbound Port, that access data from outside the application) which requires implementation of it’s defined interface into a Adapter (read “Repository” – this is the bad part of hexagonal which ambiguates the “Adapter” actor layer with our well known “Adapter” design pattern).

MongoDB Adapter Implementation for BadgeReader:

As ReplayAPI already implemented as custom-tailored micro orm for the solution, use the builder MongoDBRepositoryBuilder[T common.BaseEntity] to create the corresponding instance and Register in the container as a Right/Output/Outbound/Driven adapter for BadgeReader

Same for the other core entities:

item.title: [REPL-97] EPIC: "Challenge" Support (BugReport's Upstream Domain)
item.description:
Summary: Implement "Challenge" Module for Glitch/Bug Reporting / Analysis

Description:

As CS2 evolves, it's crucial to have a mechanism for addressing game-breaking glitches or bugs that may occur during tournament matches. This feature request proposes the implementation of a "Challenge" module within the ReplayAPI to handle such situations, as this “fiction” story below generated by AI:

The Decisive 15th Round (generated by Gemini)

The tension was palpable. It was the 15th round of a crucial match in the ESL Pro League. "FaZe Clan" and "Natus Vincere" were locked in an intense battle, with the score tied at 7-7. Every round mattered, every decision could swing the momentum.

As the round began, "s1mple," Na`Vi's star AWPer, peeked out from "A-Long" on Mirage. He caught a glimpse of "broky," FaZe's own sniper, adjusting his position at "Palace." A split-second decision, a flick of the wrist, and a shot rang out.

But something was amiss. The kill feed showed "broky" had been eliminated, yet he was still visible on the screen,seemingly oblivious to the fatal shot. A collective gasp rose from the audience, both online and in the arena. A game-breaking bug had reared its ugly head at the worst possible time.

The Chaos Unfolds

The casters scrambled to make sense of the situation. "Is this real? Did 's1mple' just kill a ghost?" one commentator exclaimed. The players themselves were confused. "broky" continued playing, even planting the bomb at "A-Site" while his spectral form roamed the map.

Na`Vi, unaware of the bug's implications, hesitated. Should they push the site, risking a surprise flank from a "dead" player? Or should they play it safe, allowing the bomb to explode and potentially losing the round?

Meanwhile, FaZe Clan, recognizing the advantage the bug had given them, exploited the situation. The "ghost" of "broky" distracted Na`Vi, drawing their attention away from the real "broky" who was calmly defusing the bomb.

The Aftermath

Na`Vi lost the round and, subsequently, the match. The controversy surrounding the bugged round overshadowed their valiant efforts throughout the game. Post-match discussions erupted online, with fans and analysts debating the fairness of the outcome.

The incident highlighted a critical flaw in the competitive landscape of CS2: the lack of a reliable pause and review system for dealing with game-breaking bugs. If a pause feature had been available, the referees could have analyzed the situation, potentially restarting the round and ensuring a fair outcome for both teams.

The Call for Change

The "ghost broky" incident became a rallying cry for change within the CS2 community. Players, coaches, and fans alike demanded a system that could address such critical bugs in real time.

Eventually, Valve responded by implementing a pause and review feature in CS2. Teams were now able to request a pause if they suspected a bug had significantly impacted the round. This allowed referees to review the gameplay, determine the extent of the bug's influence, and decide on a course of action – whether to restart the round, adjust the score, or continue play.

Goals:

  • Provide a way for team managers or players to request a pause and review of a round due to a suspected bug or glitch.
  • Enable referees/admins to analyze the reported incident using ReplayAPI's tools.
  • Facilitate a voting mechanism (optional/TBD) among players to determine whether the round should be restarted.
  • Log detailed information about the glitch, including tick range, player actions, and potential impact on the round outcome.

Draft Requirements (IF Considering Possible Feature Support):

  • As a team manager, I want to be able to pause the match and request a review if I believe a bug has occurred that significantly impacts the round's fairness.
  • As a player, I want the ability to flag potential glitches and provide information to the referee for review.
  • As a referee, I want to be able to access a detailed replay of the round, including tick-by-tick analysis, to determine if a bug has occurred and how it has affected the game.
  • As a tournament organizer, I want a system that ensures fair play and resolves game-breaking bugs in a transparent and timely manner.

Draft Mechanics

  • Upon challenge, the match is paused, and a notification is sent to the referee/admin.
  • Referees/admins can review the reported incident using ReplayAPI's existing analysis tools.
  • The system allows for (optional/TO BE DEFINED) player voting on whether to restart the round.
  • A "Glitch Details" model is created to store:
    • MatchID
    • RoundNumber
    • TickRange
    • Player Initiating Challenge (if applicable)
    • Description of the Glitch
    • Type/Etc
    • Referee Decision (restart, adjust score, continue play, tbd…)
  • Glitch details are logged for future analysis and bug fixing.

Task Breakdown:

  1. Database Schema Design:
    • Create "Glitch Details" model in the database.
  2. Backend API Implementation:
    • Add endpoints for challenge requests, referee actions, and voting.
    • Implement logic to handle challenges and update the game state accordingly.

By addressing this issue, the ReplayAPI can become an even more valuable tool for ensuring fair play and maintaining the competitive integrity of CS2.

item.title: [REPL-76] [SDK][gRPC] Stats Schema (Protobuff/Sendtables)
item.description:
DRAFT (SDK Models/Schema + Optimization => Reduce Bandwidth of intense data by applying Send-table pattern through gRPC using Protobuff schemas)

Define Protobuf Schemas (.proto Files)

  1. Create .proto files to define the structure of your messages (entities) for gRPC communication. This is where we’ll translate our Go structs into Protobuf definitions. Here's an example for CSEconomyStats entity:
Protocol Buffers
syntax = "proto3";

package replay_api;

// Represents the economic state of a team in a round.
enum CSEconomyState {
  UNDEFINED = 0;
  PISTOL_ROUND = 1;
  FULL_BUY = 2;
  FULL_BUY_SECOND = 3;
  HALF_BUY = 4;
  // ... (rest of the CSEconomyState enum and props)
}

// Totalizer for economic values will also become SENDTABLEs!!
message CSEconomyTotalizer {
  int32 total = 1;
  int32 avg = 2;
  int32 median = 3;
  int32 min = 4;
  int32 max = 5;
}

// Return on investment (ROI) for economic items. -- Same thing!
message CSEconomyROI {
  int32 direct_frags = 1;
  int32 assistance_frags = 2;
  int32 entry_frags = 3;
  int32 exit_frags = 4;
  int32 trade_frags = 5;
}

// Statistics for a specific economic item.
message CSEconomyItemStats {
  int32 count = 1;
  CSEconomyTotalizer price = 2;
  CSEconomyROI frags = 3;
  CSEconomyTotalizer damage = 4;
  CSEconomyTotalizer reward = 5;
}

// Comprehensive economic statistics for a CS:GO round or match.
message CSEconomyStats {
  CSEconomyState state = 1;
  int32 total_spend = 2;
  // ... (rest of the fields)
}

2. Generate Go Code from Protobuf Schemas

Use the Protobuf compiler (protoc) to generate Go code from our .proto files. This will create Go structs that correspond to your Protobuf messages.

Bash
protoc --go_out=. --go_opt=paths=source_relative \
    --go-grpc_out=. --go-grpc_opt=paths=source_relative \
    replay_api_schema.proto
  1. Implement gRPC Service
  2. Define Service: Create a gRPC service definition (.proto) that specifies the methods for transmitting your game data. 
    Protocol Buffers
    service GameDataService {
  rpc GetRoundEconomyStats (RoundRequest) returns (CSEconomyStats) {}
  // ... other methods for player stats, trajectories, etc.
}
  3. Implement the Service: In our Go server, implement the methods defined in the gRPC service. These methods will retrieve the necessary data from your analysis engine or database and package it into the generated Protobuf messages.
  4. Run gRPC Server: Start the replay-api (go) with gRPC driving adapter to listen for incoming requests.
  5. Send Data over gRPC

In our replay api Go code (e.g., replay demo parser handler), use the generated gRPC client to send the Protobuf messages to gRPC endpoint (NOT REST, GRPC (INTERNAL UDP)). This will efficiently transfer the structured data over the network.

Example gRPC Client Code:

Go
// ... in Go handler
func EconomyEvent(p dem.Parser, matchContext *state.CS2MatchContext, out chan replay_entity.GameEvent) func(e evt.RoundFreezetimeEnd) { 
  return func(event evt.RoundFreezetimeEnd) {
    // ... our existing logic
    economyStats := &cs_entity.CSEconomyStats{
      State: cs_entity.CSEconomyState_FULL_BUY, // Example
      // ... set other fields
    }

    // Send economyStats to the gRPC server using the generated client
    _, err := gameDataClient.GetRoundEconomyStats(ctx, &replay_sdk.RoundRequest{RoundId: roundIndex})
    if err != nil {
      // Handle error
    }
  }
}

Best Practices for ***OPTIMIZATION*:

  • Compression: Use gRPC's built-in compression (e.g., gzip) to reduce message size.
  • Caching: Cache frequently requested data on the server-side.
  • Stream Data: If have large amounts of data (e.g., trajectories), consider using gRPC streaming to send it in chunks.
  • Message Structure: Design Protobuf messages to be as compact as possible. Avoid unnecessary nesting or fields.

item.title: [REPL-75] [PARSER] Map-Specific Player Profiles Stats
item.description:
Core Concept:

Instead of a single, generalized player report, generate map-specific player profiles that highlight the variations in a player's strengths, weaknesses, and tendencies based on the map they're playing. This allows for a more granular understanding of how a player adapts to different environments and strategic demands.

Structure of the Map-Specific Player Profile:

  1. Map Overview:
    • Map Name and Image: Visual representation for quick reference.
    • Player Role on this Map: Clearly indicate the primary role the player typically plays (Entry Fragger, Support, Lurker, etc.).
    • Overall Rating: A consolidated rating (e.g., 1-10) that summarizes the player's performance on this map.
  2. Key Performance Indicators (KPIs):
    • Map-Specific Stats:
      • K/D/A (Kills/Deaths/Assists)
      • ADR (Average Damage per Round)
      • KAST (Percentage of rounds with Kill, Assist, Survive, or Trade)
      • HLTV Rating (If available)
      • Impact Rating (A custom metric combining various stats)
    • Role-Specific Stats (Dynamically generated based on the player's role):
      • Entry Fragger: Opening duel success rate, first-kill percentage.
      • Support: Flash assists, grenade effectiveness (damage/kills).
      • AWPer: AWP kills per round, AWP accuracy.
      • Lurker: Flank success rate, impact in late-round situations.
  3. Heatmaps and Visualizations:
    • Heatmap Layers: Show separate heatmaps for:
      • Kills: Where the player gets most of their kills.
      • Deaths: Where the player tends to die.
      • Utility Usage: Grenade throws, smoke placements, etc.
    • 3D Heatmap (R3F): Consider using R3F for a more immersive 3D heatmap overlay on the map model itself.
    • Trajectory Visualization: Show the player's typical movement paths and common angles.
    • Vision Cones: Optionally, visualize areas visible to the player at different times.
  4. Round-by-Round Analysis:
    • Concise Summary: Provide a quick overview of the player's performance in each round (K/D/A, impact highlights).
    • Round Type Filters: Allow filtering by win/loss, side (T/CT), and round outcome (e.g., bomb plant, defuse).
    • Notable Rounds: Automatically highlight exceptional rounds (clutches, multi-kills, significant utility impact).
  5. Strategic Insights:
    • Tendency Analysis: Identify the player's tendencies on specific areas of the map (e.g., aggressive pushes,passive holds).
    • Weakness Exploitation: Suggest areas where the player might be vulnerable based on their death heatmap.
    • Teammate Synergy: Highlight how the player interacts with their teammates on this map (trades, coordinated plays).
  6. Comparisons:
    • Map-to-Map: Allow comparisons between the player's profiles on different maps.
    • Role Comparisons: Compare the player's performance in different roles (if they play multiple roles).
    • Team Comparisons: Compare the player's stats to team averages on the same map.

Implementation Notes:

  • ReplayAPI: Use the ReplayAPI to extract all relevant data (player positions, events, game state, etc.).
  • Data Processing: Develop custom algorithms to analyze the data and generate map-specific stats and insights.
  • Frontend: Build the interactive report UI using React, Next.js, and R3F for 3D visualization.
  • Backend (Optional): If you have complex analysis, consider a backend service (e.g., Python with data science libraries) to handle the heavy lifting.

Example Output (Summary):

  • Inferno: Aggressive entry fragger, excels at A site executes but struggles on B site defense.
  • Mirage: Solid all-around rifler, consistent utility usage for mid control.
  • Nuke: Passive AWPer, effective at holding angles but needs to improve on clutch situations.

Benefits:

  • Actionable Insights: Provides coaches with targeted information for improving a player's performance on specific maps.
  • Personalized Training: Players can focus on areas where they need improvement on each map.
  • Deeper Understanding: Reveals hidden patterns and tendencies that might not be apparent in general reports.
  • Competitive Edge: Allows teams to gain a tactical advantage by understanding how opponents play on different maps.

Why Use a Quadtree for CS Replay Analysis?

  1. Efficiency for Large Datasets: CS matches generate a massive amount of data, especially when tracking player and object positions over time. Quadtrees excel at handling large spatial datasets, significantly reducing the time it takes to find objects within a specific region compared to brute-force approaches.
  2. Targeted Searches: Quadtrees allow for targeted searches within specific areas of interest (e.g., bomb sites, chokepoints, vision cones). This is crucial for efficiently identifying events and interactions that occur in specific locations.
  3. Dynamic Updates: Quadtrees can be dynamically updated as players and objects move. This enables real-time analysis and rendering of overlays without having to rebuild the entire data structure from scratch.
  4. Reduced Computational Overhead: By partitioning the map into quadrants, quadtrees reduce the number of distance calculations needed to determine if an object is within a given area. This is particularly beneficial for complex shapes like vision cones or grenade trajectories.
  5. Memory Optimization (Optional): If you're storing large amounts of historical data, quadtrees can be more memory-efficient than storing all object positions in a flat list, especially when objects are clustered together.

func findPlayersInBombsiteQuadtree(qt *quadtree.Quadtree, bombsiteArea orb.Polygon) []orb.Pointer {

        if !node.Bound().Intersects(bombsiteArea.Bound()) {

        return node.Nodes() // Continue searching in child nodes
    })
}

func (p Player) InVisionCone(vc VisionCone) bool {
    // Vector from player to target
    toTarget := p.Position().Sub(vc.Origin)

    // Check distance
    distance := toTarget.Length()
    if distance > vc.Range {
        return false
    }

    // Check horizontal angle
    toTargetFlat := common.Vector{X: toTarget.X, Y: toTarget.Y} // Project onto horizontal plane
    dotProduct := toTargetFlat.Dot(vc.ViewDirection)
    angle := math.Acos(dotProduct / (toTargetFlat.Length() * vc.ViewDirection.Length()))
    if angle > vc.HorizontalFOV / 2 {
        return false
    }

    // Check vertical angle
    verticalAngle := math.Atan2(toTarget.Z, toTargetFlat.Length())
    if verticalAngle < -vc.VerticalFOV/2 || verticalAngle > vc.VerticalFOV/2 {
        return false
    }

    // Handle smoke obscuring vision
    if isInSmoke(p.Position(), vc.SmokePositions) {
        return false
    }

    return true
}

item.title: [REPL-72] [PARSER][Research*] Vision Cone (Angles by Tick)
item.description:
1. Accurate Representation: Determine the most precise method for calculating vision cones within the CS game engine. This includes considering factors like player height, crouch status, view angles, and map geometry.
  2. Performance Optimization: Identify techniques to optimize the calculation and storage of vision cone data to ensure the backend processor can handle real-time analysis without significant performance impact.
  3. Data Structure and Format: Define an efficient data structure to represent vision cones in a way that is easily consumable by the overlay rendering engine.

Research Methods

  1. Source Engine Deep Dive:
    • Thoroughly investigate the Source Engine's internal rendering and visibility systems.
    • Explore the possibility of accessing relevant APIs or modifying the game engine to extract vision cone data directly.
    • Analyze demo files to understand how view angles and player positions are encoded and how they relate to actual visibility in-game.
  2. 3D Geometry and Raytracing:
    • Study 3D geometry concepts like frustums and ray-triangle intersections.
    • Implement raytracing algorithms in Go to simulate lines of sight from the player's perspective and determine which parts of the map are visible.
    • Evaluate the performance impact of raytracing in a real-time context and explore optimization techniques (e.g., spatial partitioning, bounding volume hierarchies).
  3. Open-Source Projects:
    • Analyze existing open-source projects that deal with CS demo parsing or map analysis.
    • Investigate libraries or tools that provide functionality for calculating vision cones or similar visibility calculations.
      • Examples: libraries (for navigation mesh generation), csgo-demo-viewer (for demo visualization), and projects related to CS development.

Potential Approaches

  1. Direct Source Engine Integration (Ideal):
    • Pros: The most accurate method, as it leverages the game engine's own calculations for visibility.
    • Cons: Requires in-depth knowledge of the Source Engine, potential compatibility issues with future updates,and may be challenging to implement due to lack of official documentation.
  2. Hybrid Approach (Recommended):
    • Pros: Combines the accuracy of demo data with the flexibility of external calculations.
    • Cons: Requires careful calibration and testing to ensure consistency with the game engine's behavior.
  3. Purely External Calculation (Backup):
    • Pros: Most flexible approach, can be tailored to specific needs.
    • Cons: Potentially less accurate than using the game engine, requires meticulous implementation of 3D geometry and raytracing algorithms.

Data Structure for Vision Cones

A VisionCone struct could contain the following information:

Go
type VisionCone struct {
    PlayerName    string
    Origin        common.Vector   // Player's eye position
    Direction     common.Vector   // View direction vector
    HorizontalFOV float64         // Horizontal field of view (in degrees)
    VerticalFOV   float64         // Vertical field of view (in degrees)
    Range         float64         // Maximum view distance
    Polygon       []common.Vector // Vertices of the vision cone polygon (2D)
}

Performance Optimizations

  • Caching: Store pre-calculated vision cone data for common scenarios (e.g., per player position on a map).
  • Spatial Indexing: Use spatial data structures (e.g., quadtrees, R-trees) to efficiently query for objects within a vision cone.
  • Adaptive Resolution: Adjust the level of detail of vision cone calculations based on the required accuracy and available processing power.

Additional Considerations

  • Player Height and Crouching: Account for changes in player height and crouching status when calculating vision cones.
  • Grenade Effects: Incorporate the effects of smoke grenades, which can obscure vision and create complex shapes that need to be accounted for.
  • Wall Penetration: Determine if and how much bullets can penetrate walls to adjust visibility calculations accordingly.

Deliverables

  1. Technical Report: Summarizing the research findings, chosen approach, implementation details, and performance benchmarks.
  2. Go Library: A well-documented Go library for calculating and representing vision cones, integrated with the LeetGaming ReplayAPI.
  3. Demo Implementation: A working demo showcasing the integration of vision cone data with the overlay rendering engine.

  • Implementation and testing: 4 weeks
  • Integration and optimization: 2 weeks

item.title: [REPL-69] EPIC: CS2MatchQL/CS2QL R (Language & Compiler)
item.description:
Overall Architecture

The architecture will follow a classic compiler pipeline:

  1. Lexical Analysis (Lexer): Breaks down the input query into tokens (keywords, identifiers, operators, literals).
  2. Syntax Analysis (Parser): Constructs an Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) from the tokens, representing the query's structure.
  3. Semantic Analysis: Validates the AST, performs type checking, and resolves references.
  4. Optimization (Optional): Transforms the AST to improve query performance.
  5. Code Generation: Generates an executable representation of the query (e.g., MongoDB aggregation pipeline).

Framework and Library Choices

  • Lexer & Parser:
    • Golex: A powerful lexical analyzer generator for Go. It allows you to define regular expressions for tokens and generates efficient code to recognize them.
    • Goparser: A versatile parser generator for Go. You can define the grammar of CS2MatchQL using BNF (Backus-Naur Form) or EBNF (Extended BNF), and Goparser will generate a parser that can construct the AST.
  • Abstract Syntax Tree (AST):
    • Go AST Library: Leverage the standard Go AST library (go/ast) to define the structure of the AST nodes.This allows you to easily manipulate and traverse the AST during semantic analysis and code generation.
  • Semantic Analysis:
    • Go's Type System: Utilize Go's static type system to enforce type safety and catch errors during compilation. Define custom types for different CS2MatchQL constructs (events, states, operators) and check for type compatibility.
    • Symbol Table: Maintain a symbol table to track variable declarations and scope. This is essential for resolving references and ensuring that variables are used correctly.
  • Code Generation:
    • MongoDB Driver: Use the official MongoDB Go driver (mongo-go-driver) to construct MongoDB aggregation pipelines from the AST.
  • Additional Libraries:
    • Error Handling: Consider using a library like pkg/errors for better error handling and propagation.
    • Logging: Use a logging framework like logrus or zap for debugging and monitoring.
    • Testing: Write comprehensive unit and integration tests using a framework like testify to ensure the correctness of the compiler.

Detailed Implementation

  1. Lexer (Golex):
    • Define regular expressions for CS2MatchQL tokens (keywords, identifiers, operators, literals).
    • Use Golex to generate the lexer code.
  2. Parser (Goparser):
    • Define the CS2MatchQL grammar using BNF or EBNF.
    • Use Goparser to generate the parser code.
    • Construct the AST based on the parsed tokens.
  3. Semantic Analysis:
    • Validate the AST to ensure it adheres to the language's rules.
    • Perform type checking on expressions and assignments.
    • Resolve references to variables and functions.
  4. Optimization (Optional):
    • Identify redundant calculations or conditions.
    • Rearrange expressions to improve efficiency.
    • Consider using caching mechanisms for frequently used queries.
  5. Code Generation (MongoDB Aggregation):
    • Traverse the AST and translate it into a MongoDB aggregation pipeline.
    • Use the MongoDB Go driver to construct and execute the aggregation pipeline.
    • Handle errors gracefully and provide informative error messages.

Example: Parsing a Simple Query

Go
// (Simplified example)
query := "match round 15 where event(Kill) and killer.name = 'sound'"
lexer := NewLexer(query)
parser := NewParser()

// Parse the query
ast, err := parser.Parse(lexer) 
// ... (Handle errors)

// Analyze and optimize the AST
// ...

// Generate MongoDB query
mongoQuery := generateMongoDBQuery(ast)
// ...

Testing and Validation

  • Unit Tests: Write unit tests for each component (lexer, parser, analyzer, code generator) to ensure they function correctly in isolation.
  • Integration Tests: Test the entire compiler pipeline with various valid and invalid queries.
  • Performance Tests: Measure the performance of the compiler with large and complex queries.
  • Fuzz Testing: Use fuzz testing to discover potential vulnerabilities and edge cases.

Additional Considerations

  • Error Reporting: Design a user-friendly error reporting mechanism that provides clear and actionable feedback to users.
  • IDE Integration: Explore creating language plugins for popular IDEs (e.g., VSCode) to provide syntax highlighting, code completion, and error checking for CS2MatchQL.
  • Documentation: Maintain comprehensive documentation that includes the language specification, tutorials, examples, and API references.

Ubiquitous Language (draft v1)

General Gameplay

  • Round: A single period of play within a match.
  • Half: One of two halves in a match, typically 15 rounds each.
  • Side: The team a player is on (T or Counter-T).
  • Bombsite (or Site): The designated areas (A and B) where Ts can plant the bomb.
  • Spawn: The starting area for each team.
  • Buy Time/Freeze Time: The initial phases of a round where players can purchase weapons and equipment.

Weapons and Equipment

  • AWP: The most powerful sniper rifle in the game.
  • Rifle: Primary long-range weapon (e.g., AK-47, M4A4).
  • SMG: Submachine gun, good for close-quarters combat (e.g., MP9, MAC-10).
  • Pistol: Sidearm used in early rounds or for quick kills (e.g., USP-S, Glock-18).
  • Utility: Non-lethal equipment (e.g., grenades, flashbangs, smoke grenades, molotovs/incendiaries).
  • Kevlar/Armor: Protective gear that reduces damage.
  • Helmet: Head protection that reduces headshot damage.
  • Defuse Kit: A tool that allows Counter-Ts to defuse the bomb faster.

Player Actions

  • Frag: A kill.
  • Headshot: A kill with a bullet to the head.
  • Kill: Eliminating an enemy player.
  • Assist: Helping a teammate get a kill (e.g., by damaging the enemy).
  • Clutch: Winning a round despite being outnumbered.
  • Ace: Killing all five members of the enemy team in a single round.
  • Entry Frag: The first kill in a round, typically secured by the player entering a bombsite first.
  • Retake: Counter-Ts retaking control of a bombsite after the bomb has been planted.
  • Rotate: A team moving from one area of the map to another.
  • Peek: Briefly exposing oneself from cover to gather information or take a shot.
  • Boost: One player crouching to allow another to jump on their head for a height advantage.

Team Strategies

  • Execute: A coordinated attack on a bombsite.
  • Default: A standard setup where players hold specific positions on the map.
  • Rush: A fast, aggressive attack on a bombsite.
  • Split: Dividing the team to attack multiple areas simultaneously.
  • Fake: A deceptive maneuver to distract the enemy team.
  • Eco: A round where a team buys minimal or no equipment to save money.
  • Force Buy: A round where a team spends most of its money on weapons and equipment despite having low funds.

Advanced Terms

  • Peeker's Advantage: The advantage a player has when peeking around a corner due to network latency and game mechanics.
  • Crosshair Placement: The position of a player's crosshair in anticipation of an enemy.
  • Spray Pattern: The pattern in which bullets spread when firing a weapon in automatic mode.
  • Recoil Control: The technique of managing a weapon's recoil to maintain accuracy.
  • Utility Usage: The strategic deployment of grenades and other non-lethal equipment.

Additional Terms

  • Demo: A recording of a match that can be reviewed.
  • Config: A player's personalized game settings.
  • MM/Matchmaking: The automated system for finding online matches.
  • Rank: A player's competitive skill rating.
  • Overtime: Additional rounds played if a match ends in a tie.

General Calls

  • Default: Establishing a standard setup, with players holding specific positions on the map.
  • Slow: A cautious approach, prioritizing information gathering and map control.
  • Fast: An aggressive push onto a bombsite or area of the map.
  • Eco: A round where the team buys minimal equipment to save money.
  • Force Buy: A round where the team spends most of its money despite having low funds.
  • Save: A round where the team intentionally avoids engaging in combat to preserve weapons for the next round.

T-Side Calls

  • Execute A/B: A coordinated attack on a specific bombsite.
  • Split A/B: Dividing the team to attack both bombsites simultaneously.
  • Late Execute: Delaying the attack until later in the round to catch the defenders off guard.
  • Fake A/B: A deceptive maneuver to make the defenders think you're attacking one site while actually hitting the other.
  • Contact: Push forward and engage the enemy to gather information.
  • Stack A/B: Focusing all players on a single bombsite for a concentrated attack.

Counter-T-Side Calls

  • Hold A/B: Defending a specific bombsite.
  • Rotate A/B: Moving players from one bombsite to another to counter the T attack.
  • Aggressive A/B: Pushing out from a bombsite to actively hunt for Ts.
  • Stack A/B: Focusing all players on a single bombsite for a strong defense.
  • Bait: Intentionally leaving a bombsite vulnerable to lure the Ts into a trap.
  • Retake: Reclaiming a bombsite after it has been planted.

Additional Calls (More Specific)

  • Boost Me (Position): Requesting a boost to a specific location.
  • Flash (Position): Asking a teammate to throw a flashbang at a specific location.
  • Smoke (Position): Requesting a smoke grenade to be thrown at a specific location.
  • Molly (Position): Requesting a molotov or incendiary grenade to be thrown at a specific location.
  • Watch (Position): Asking a teammate to keep an eye on a specific area.
  • Lurker (Position): Assigning a player to a flanking or isolated position.
  • Second Mid/Second A/Second B: Asking for a teammate to provide additional support to a specific area.

Examples of Calls

  • "Default B, slow!"
  • "Execute A on my go!"
  • "Split A, two on B!"
  • "Fake B, hit A on my call!"
  • "Eco, save!"
  • "Force buy, full A!"
  • "Hold B, aggressive CT!"
  • "Rotate to A, one stays on B!"
  • "Bait B, stack A!"
  • "Retake A, slow and steady!"

Important Note:

The specific calls and strategies used can vary greatly depending on the map, team composition, and individual playstyles.

Effective communication and coordination are crucial for executing these calls successfully.

Philosophy

CS2MatchQL is designed to empower analysts, coaches, and enthusiasts to deeply understand the intricacies of CS:2 matches. It focuses on:

  • State Awareness: Tracks the evolving state of the game (e.g., player positions, weapon states, bomb status) for context-rich queries.
  • Round-Based Analysis: Easily isolate specific rounds or phases within a round for detailed analysis.
  • Statistical Insights: Provides built-in functions to calculate essential stats (K/D ratios, ADR, economic trends).
  • Pattern Recognition: Identifies recurring strategic patterns within matches (e.g., executes, retakes, rotations).

Keywords and Structure

  • match: The root of every query, defining the scope of the match being analyzed.
  • round: Narrows the scope to a specific round number or a range of rounds.
  • event: Filters for specific game events (e.g., Kill, Plant, Buy, PositionUpdate).
  • state: Queries the game state at a specific time or in relation to an event.
  • stats: Calculates aggregated statistics for players, teams, or across the match.

Intelligent Snippets

  1. Identifying Clutch Situations:
match
where round.phase = 'PostPlant'
  and event(Kill)
  and state.ctAlive = 1
  and state.tAlive <= 2
  • Benefit: Pinpoints clutch scenarios where a CT player eliminates multiple Ts in a post-plant situation.
  1. Analyzing Economy Impact:

stats.team('T').averageEquipmentValue
  • Benefit: Reveals the average equipment value of the T side in round 15, aiding in economic analysis.
  1. Tracking Player Movement:
match
event(PositionUpdate) as pos1,
event(PositionUpdate) as pos2 
where pos1.player = 'sound'
  and pos2.player = 'sound'
  and pos2.time - pos1.time <= 5
return pos1.position, pos2.position
  • Benefit: Traces the movement of a specific player (sound) within a 5-second window, offering insights into positioning and rotations.
  1. Detecting Specific Strategies:
match round 2
where event(SmokeStart) as smoke1,
  event(SmokeStart) as smoke2,
  event(FlashbangStart) as flash
where smoke1.position ~ 'A-site'
  and smoke2.position ~ 'A-site'
  and flash.position ~ 'A-site'
  and flash.time - smoke1.time <= 2
  • Benefit: Identifies a potential execute strategy on A site in round 2, marked by the use of multiple smokes and a flashbang in quick succession.
  1. Evaluating Player Performance:
match
stats.player('sh__x').kdr,
stats.player('sh__x').adr,
stats.player('sh__x').kast
  • Benefit: Provides a comprehensive overview of a player's performance throughout the match, including K/D ratio,ADR, and KAST (percentage of rounds with a kill, assist, survival, or traded death).

Additional Features (Future)

  • Event Sequencing: Express complex patterns involving sequences of events.
  • State Comparison: Compare game states across different rounds or moments.
  • Predictive Analysis: Leverage machine learning to predict outcomes or suggest optimal strategies based on historical data.
  • Visualization Integration: Seamlessly integrate with visualization tools to display query results as interactive charts or heatmaps.

Snippets targeting a wider range of tactical and strategic insights:

  1. Identifying Fake A Execute B:
match
round r
where (
  // Early aggression towards A
  exists (
    event(SmokeStart) as aSmoke,
    event(GrenadeStart) as aGrenade
    where aSmoke.position ~ 'A-site'
      and aGrenade.position ~ 'A-site'
      and aSmoke.time < r.halfTime
      and aGrenade.time < r.halfTime

  // AND a rotation to B site later in the round

    event(BombPlant) as plant

  )
)

Benefit: Detects rounds where Ts show early aggression on A, only to rotate and plant the bomb on B.

match
event(Kill) as kill
where exists (
  state.player(kill.killer).position as pos
  where pos ~ 'Off-Angles' or pos ~ 'Flank'
)

Benefit: Finds kills made from off-angles or flanking positions, indicative of a lurker's playstyle.

  1. Identifying Eco/Half Buy/Full Buy Rounds:

stats.team('T').averageEquipmentValue as tEquip
stats.team('CT').averageEquipmentValue as ctEquip
where tEquip < 1000 // Eco
  or (tEquip >= 1000 and tEquip < 4000) // Half buy
  or (tEquip >= 4000) // Full buy

Benefit: Classifies rounds based on the average equipment value of each team, revealing their economic state.

  1. Team Weapon Power Analysis:

stats.team('CT').weaponBreakdown as ctWeapons
where ctWeapons['AWP'] >= 3

Benefit: Identifies rounds where the CT side had a significant AWP presence (3 or more), influencing their defensive strategy.

  1. Identifying Flick Shots:

event(Kill) as kill
where kill.aimPunchAngle > 5

Benefit: Detects kills where the player's crosshair moved significantly after firing the shot, suggesting a flick shot.

  • Entry Fragger Analysis: Find players with high first-kill percentages and analyze their weapon choices and positions.
  • Map Control Patterns: Track the movement of players across the map to identify areas of dominant control or frequent rotations.
  • Round Outcome Prediction: Utilize machine learning models to predict round outcomes based on early-round events (e.g., pistol round wins, first blood)

Snippets focused on aim, trajectories, and ninja defuses:

Aim-Related Snippets

where kill.hitgroup = 'head'
    • Benefit: Finds all kills that were headshots.
  2. Analyzing First Bullet Accuracy (FBA):

event(Damage) as damage
where damage.isHit
  and damage.isFirstBullet
stats.average(damage.hitgroupDistance) as avgDistance
    • Benefit: Calculates the average distance of the first bullet hit for all damage events, giving insights into a player's initial shot accuracy.
  3. Detecting Spray Control:

event(Damage) as d3
where d1.attacker = d2.attacker = d3.attacker

event(BombDefuseEnd) as defuseEnd

item.description:
Jira Ticket

Project: LeetGaming Backend

Issue Type: Task

Summary: Develop and Train Machine Learning Model for Pro Player Talent Identification

Description:

This task involves developing and training a machine learning (ML) model to predict the potential of CS2 players to become professionals. The model will take two primary inputs:

  1. Massive Serial Events: A comprehensive stream of in-game events (kills, assists, bomb events, etc.) from a player's match history.
  2. Massive Stats Object: Aggregated statistics and highlights generated from the state machine analysis, including economic data, clutch performance, and specific pro player signals.

The model should be able to analyze these large datasets and output a prediction score indicating the player's likelihood of transitioning to professional play.

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Model Selection: Choose an appropriate ML model architecture (e.g., deep neural network, gradient boosting, ensemble model) based on the available data and desired prediction accuracy.
  • Feature Engineering: Extract meaningful features from the input data to train the model effectively.
  • Model Training: Train the model on a large dataset of labeled player data (professional vs. non-professional).
  • Model Evaluation: Evaluate the model's performance using appropriate metrics (e.g., accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score) and validation techniques (e.g., cross-validation).
  • Deployment: Deploy the trained model to a production environment for inference.
  • API Integration: Integrate the model's predictions into the existing LeetGaming backend API to provide talent scores to client applications.

Technical Requirements:

  1. Data Preparation:
    • Acquire a large dataset of CS2 match data with corresponding player labels (professional/non-professional). This could be obtained through partnerships with data providers, scraping public data sources, or manual labeling.
    • Clean and preprocess the raw match data to ensure it is suitable for model training (e.g., handle missing values, normalize features).
    • Split the dataset into training, validation, and test sets to evaluate the model's performance.
  2. Feature Engineering:
    • Extract relevant features from the serial events and stats object, such as:
      • Individual Player Stats: K/D ratio, ADR, KAST, impact rating, headshot percentage, etc.
      • Pro Player Signals: Scores for the various signals defined in the previous Jira ticket.
      • Economic Performance: Total spend, utility usage, weapon choices, win rate in different economic situations.
      • Clutch Performance: Clutch win rate, clutch type distribution, etc.
      • Teamplay: Assists, flash assists, trade kills, etc.
  3. Model Selection and Training:
    • Explore different ML model architectures (neural networks, decision trees, etc.) to find the best fit for the data and task.
    • Train the model on the training set using appropriate optimization algorithms and hyperparameter tuning.
    • Validate the model on the validation set and adjust the hyperparameters as needed.
  4. Model Evaluation:
    • Evaluate the final model on the test set to assess its generalization performance.
    • Choose appropriate evaluation metrics based on the project goals (e.g., if false positives are more costly than false negatives, focus on precision).
  5. Deployment and API Integration:
    • Deploy the trained model to a scalable and reliable environment (e.g., cloud-based ML platform, containerized service).
    • Create an API endpoint to accept match data and return the model's talent prediction score for each player.
    • Consider versioning the model to allow for updates and improvements over time.

Available/Indicated Providers:

  • Cloud ML Platforms:
    • Google Cloud AI Platform
    • Amazon SageMaker
    • Microsoft Azure Machine Learning
  • ML Frameworks:
    • TensorFlow
    • PyTorch
    • scikit-learn

item.description:
Description:

This epic aims to transform game event search into a strategic asset, offering deep insights into gameplay patterns, trends, and opponent analysis. We'll achieve this by augmenting our existing MongoDB infrastructure with Elasticsearch, unlocking real-time analytics, advanced filtering, and AI-driven insights.

Technical Goals/Objectives:

  1. Elasticsearch Augmentation:
    • Data Enrichment: Enhance raw event data with calculated metrics (e.g., kill/death ratios, objective capture times) and metadata (player rankings, team compositions) before indexing into Elasticsearch.
    • Real-Time Indexing: Leverage MongoDB change streams to synchronize event data with Elasticsearch in near real-time.
    • Index Optimization: Design Elasticsearch mappings to optimize for speed and relevance in the context of competitive gaming search.
    • Query Language Expansion: Introduce Elasticsearch's Query DSL for complex filtering, aggregations, and ranking tailored to competitive analysis.
  2. Advanced Search Features:
    • Timeline Visualization: Enable users to explore events on an interactive timeline, highlighting key moments within matches.
    • Pattern Recognition: Use machine learning algorithms to identify recurring gameplay patterns (e.g.,common strategies, map hotspots) and surface them in search results.
    • Comparative Analysis: Allow users to compare event statistics across different players, teams, or matches.
    • Customizable Dashboards: Let users create personalized dashboards to track their own performance or monitor specific aspects of gameplay.
  3. Integration with Existing Systems:
    • Seamless MongoDB Integration: Maintain MongoDB as the primary data store while leveraging Elasticsearch for search and analytics.
    • API Enhancement: Extend the existing LeetGaming API to expose the new search capabilities to clients.

Technical Acceptance Criteria:

  • Elasticsearch cluster integrated with MongoDB and fully populated with enriched game event data.
  • New search API endpoints are implemented and documented.
  • Frontend search UI is updated to leverage the new features.
  • Comprehensive unit and integration tests ensure data integrity and search accuracy.
  • Performance benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in search speed and relevance compared to the existing system.

Implementation Plan:

  1. Elasticsearch Infrastructure: Set up and configure a dedicated Elasticsearch cluster optimized for search and analytics workloads.
  2. Data Enrichment Pipeline: Develop a data pipeline (e.g., using Kafka or custom scripts) to enrich raw event data and stream it into Elasticsearch.
  3. Search API Development:
    • Design API endpoints for complex search queries, aggregations, and timeline visualizations.
    • Implement authentication and authorization to protect sensitive data.
  4. Frontend Integration:
    • Update search UI components to interact with the new API.
    • Develop visualizations for timelines, patterns, and comparative analysis.
    • Allow users to create and customize dashboards.
  5. Testing & Optimization:
    • Conduct rigorous testing to ensure data accuracy, search functionality, and performance.
    • Optimize Elasticsearch queries and index settings for maximum efficiency.

Dependencies:

  • MongoDB
  • Elasticsearch
  • Kafka (or equivalent message queue for real-time data streaming)
  • Relevant Go libraries for Elasticsearch and MongoDB interaction

Out of Scope (for now):

  • Real-time event streaming to clients (potential future enhancement).

Metrics:

  • Search Latency: Time to return search results (target sub-second response times).

item.description:
Description:

This task involves setting up an on-demand Counter-Strike 2 (CS2) server on Tencent Cloud that can be dynamically provisioned and deprovisioned based on player demand. The server should provide a seamless experience for players while ensuring optimal performance and cost efficiency.

Acceptance Criteria:

Technical Requirements:

  1. Tencent Cloud Resources:
    • A Tencent Cloud account with sufficient resources (compute, storage, network) to host the CS2 server.
    • A suitable virtual machine (VM) instance type that meets the CS2 system requirements (e.g., CPU, RAM,GPU).
  2. CS2 Server Software:

    • Any additional plugins or modifications necessary for on-demand functionality.

  4. Scaling and Automation:
    • Utilize Tencent Cloud's auto-scaling capabilities to dynamically adjust server resources based on player demand.
    • Set up monitoring and alerting to detect potential issues and trigger scaling actions.
  5. Testing and Deployment:
    • Thoroughly test the server under various conditions (e.g., different player counts, different maps).
    • Create a deployment plan that minimizes downtime and ensures a smooth transition for players.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Create Tencent Cloud Resources:
    • Create a VM instance with the appropriate specifications for the CS2 server.
    • Set up necessary networking (e.g., security groups, load balancers) for the server.
  2. Install and Configure CS2 Server Software:
    • Install the CS2 Dedicated Server software on the VM instance.
    • Configure the server settings according to the project requirements.
    • Install and configure any additional plugins or modifications as needed.
  3. Set Up Scaling and Automation:
    • Configure Tencent Cloud's auto-scaling policies to scale the server resources based on player demand.
    • Set up monitoring and alerting to detect potential issues.
  4. Test and Deploy:
    • Conduct thorough testing of the server under various conditions.
    • Implement the deployment plan to make the server available to players.

Additional Considerations:

  • Consider using a containerization platform like Docker to streamline deployment and management of the CS2 server.
  • Explore the use of Tencent Cloud's Game Server Elastic-Scaling (GSES) service, which is specifically designed for game server scaling.
  • Regularly monitor the server performance and player feedback to identify areas for improvement.

Labels: CS2, Tencent Cloud, On-Demand, Server

POC:
Docker Setup for On-Demand CS2 Server on Tencent Cloud

This setup assumes basic familiarity with Docker and Tencent Cloud's container services (e.g., Tencent Kubernetes Engine - TKE).

  1. Docker Images:
  • CS2 Dedicated Server: There isn't an official Docker image for the CS2 Dedicated Server yet. You will need to build your own image based on a suitable base image (e.g., Ubuntu) and install the CS2 server software within it.The installation process will likely involve downloading the server files from SteamCMD and configuring them appropriately.
  • Game Server Management (Optional): Consider using a Docker image for game server management software like Agones (for Kubernetes) or Pterodactyl. These tools can help with scaling, monitoring, and managing your CS2 server instances.
  1. Dockerfile (for CS2 Dedicated Server Image):
Dockerfile
# Use a suitable base image (e.g., Ubuntu)
FROM ubuntu:latest

# Install necessary dependencies (SteamCMD, screen, etc.)
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y \
    steamcmd \
    screen \
    # ... other dependencies

# Set up the CS2 server user
RUN useradd -m cs2server

# Download and install the CS2 Dedicated Server (replace with your actual app ID)
USER cs2server
RUN steamcmd +login anonymous +force_install_dir /home/cs2server/server +app_update 740 validate +quit

# Expose the necessary ports
EXPOSE 27015/udp
EXPOSE 27015/tcp
# ... other ports if needed

# Set up a script to start the server
COPY start_server.sh /home/cs2server/
RUN chmod +x /home/cs2server/start_server.sh

# Start the server on container launch
CMD ["/home/cs2server/start_server.sh"]
  1. start_server.sh (Example):
Bash
#!/bin/bash
# Replace with 1337gg params
screen -S cs2server -dmS cs2server ./srcds_run -game csgo -console -usercon +game_type 0 +game_mode 0 +mapgroup mg_active +map de_dust2
  1. Tencent Cloud Configuration:
  • Container Registry: Push your custom CS2 server Docker image to a Tencent Cloud Container Registry (TCR) instance.
  • Kubernetes Cluster (If using TKE):
    • Create a Kubernetes cluster on TKE.
    • Set up Agones (if using) for game server management.
    • Deploy your CS2 server image as a StatefulSet or Deployment, depending on your scaling needs.
  • Scaling: Configure auto-scaling rules based on metrics like CPU usage or player count. TKE offers Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) for this purpose.

Additional Considerations:

  • Storage: If you need persistent storage for server data (e.g., demos, configuration files), set up a persistent volume claim (PVC) in Kubernetes or use Tencent Cloud's file storage services.
  • Networking: Ensure proper network configuration for your container instances, including security groups and load balancing.
  • Monitoring and Logging: Set up monitoring and logging to track server performance and player activity.

Important Notes:

  • These are general guidelines. The specific implementation may vary depending on your exact requirements and preferences.
  • The CS2 Dedicated Server software is still under development, so you may need to adjust your Docker image and configuration as the software evolves.
  • Consult Tencent Cloud's documentation and support resources for assistance with specific configurations and deployments.

item.title: [REPL-27] EPIC: Advanced Application Performance Monitoring (APM) Implementation
item.description:
Description:

Establish a robust and comprehensive Application Performance Monitoring (APM) strategy to ensure optimal performance, reliability, and user experience for LeetGraming.PRO, utilizing industry-leading tools and best practices to gain deep insights into application behavior, identify bottlenecks, and proactively resolve issues.

Goals:

  1. Comprehensive Monitoring:
    • End-to-End Visibility: Monitor the entire application stack, including frontend (web and mobile), backend services, databases, and infrastructure.
    • Key Metrics: Track critical performance metrics such as:
      • Response times (server-side, client-side)
      • Error rates and exceptions
      • Transaction traces and request flows
      • Resource utilization (CPU, memory, disk I/O, network)
      • User experience metrics (page load times, interactions)
    • Real-time Alerts: Set up alerts to notify relevant teams immediately when performance thresholds are breached or anomalies are detected.
  2. Distributed Tracing:
    • Trace Context Propagation: Implement distributed tracing to track requests across different services and components.
    • Visualization: Utilize tools like Jaeger or Zipkin to visualize request traces and identify performance bottlenecks in complex interactions.
    • Root Cause Analysis: Quickly pinpoint the root cause of performance issues by analyzing distributed traces.
  3. Root Cause Analysis and Troubleshooting:
    • Error Profiling: Profile application code to identify slow or resource-intensive functions.
    • Log Analysis: Correlate logs from different components to understand the sequence of events leading to errors or performance issues.
    • Infrastructure Monitoring: Monitor infrastructure metrics (e.g., CPU, memory, disk usage) to correlate them with application performance.
  4. Synthetic Monitoring:
    • Proactive Testing: Set up synthetic monitoring to simulate user interactions and proactively detect issues before they impact real users.
    • Global Monitoring: Use geographically distributed monitors to test performance from different locations.
    • API Monitoring: Monitor the performance and availability of critical APIs.
  5. Real User Monitoring (RUM):
    • User-Centric Insights: Gain insights into how real users experience the application in different browsers,devices, and locations.
    • Performance Measurement: Measure page load times, user interactions, and other client-side metrics.
    • Error Reporting: Collect data on JavaScript errors and exceptions that occur in the user's browser.

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Comprehensive Monitoring: All critical components and metrics are monitored effectively.
  • Rapid Issue Identification: Performance bottlenecks and errors are quickly identified and isolated.
  • Root Cause Analysis: The root cause of performance issues is determined efficiently.
  • Proactive Problem Solving: Potential problems are detected before they impact users through synthetic monitoring.
  • Improved User Experience: Application performance is optimized, resulting in a faster and more responsive experience for users.

Technical Considerations:

  • APM Tool Selection: Evaluate and choose an APM tool that fits your requirements and budget (e.g., New Relic,Datadog, AppDynamics, Dynatrace).
  • Instrumentation: Instrument your application code to collect relevant performance data.
  • Alerting and Notification: Configure alerting thresholds and notification channels to ensure timely responses to performance issues.
  • Integration with Logging: Integrate the APM tool with your logging infrastructure for centralized log analysis and correlation.
  • Infrastructure Monitoring: Implement monitoring for your cloud infrastructure or on-premises servers.

Goals:

  1. Infrastructure as Code (IaC):
    • Tool Selection: Choose a leading IaC tool like Terraform or AWS CloudFormation to define and manage infrastructure resources declaratively.
    • Modular Structure: Organize infrastructure code into reusable modules for better maintainability and scalability.
    • Environment Management: Create separate environments (e.g., development, staging, production) to isolate changes and enable testing.
    • Version Control: Store IaC code in a version control system (e.g., Git) to track changes and enable collaboration.
  2. CI/CD Pipeline:
    • Pipeline Definition: Design a CI/CD pipeline using tools like GitHub Actions, GitLab CI/CD, or Jenkins.
    • Stages: Define distinct stages for building, testing, and deploying code (e.g., unit tests, integration tests, linting, security scans, deployment).
    • Automation: Automate every step of the pipeline, from code changes to production deployment.
    • Feedback Loops: Integrate feedback mechanisms (e.g., automated tests, monitoring alerts) to quickly identify and address issues.
    • Rollbacks: Implement automated rollback procedures in case of failed deployments.
  3. Cloud Provider Selection (AWS or Tencent):
    • Evaluation: Assess the pros and cons of both AWS (Amazon Web Services) and Tencent Cloud based on your specific requirements, such as:
      • Cost-effectiveness
      • Regional availability
      • Service offerings
      • Ease of use
      • Security features
    • Decision: Choose the cloud provider that best aligns with your needs and budget.

item.title: [REPL-22] EPIC: Global Data Privacy Compliance and Security
item.description:
Description:

Establish and maintain LeetGraming.PRO's commitment to the highest standards of data privacy and security worldwide, complying with GDPR, CCPA, LGPD, and other relevant regulations while implementing robust measures to protect user data and build trust.

Goals:

  1. Comprehensive Data Privacy Compliance:
    • GDPR, CCPA, LGPD: Conduct a thorough assessment and implement measures to comply with the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), the Brazilian General Data Protection Law (LGPD), and any other relevant data protection laws in the regions where the platform operates.
    • Data Minimization: Collect only the minimum necessary personal data from users, ensuring it is relevant and proportionate to the services provided.
    • Transparency and User Control: Provide clear and accessible privacy notices, outlining data collection practices, purposes, and legal bases for processing. Empower users with tools to manage their data and exercise their rights (access, rectification, erasure, etc.).
    • Consent Management: Obtain explicit and informed consent for data processing activities, including granular options for opting in or out of specific features or data uses.
    • Cross-Border Data Transfers: Ensure compliance with data transfer mechanisms (e.g., Standard Contractual Clauses, Binding Corporate Rules) when transferring data across borders.
  2. Robust Security Measures:
    • Encryption: Utilize strong encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256) for both data at rest (database encryption) and data in transit (HTTPS).
    • Access Controls: Implement strict access controls to restrict data access to authorized personnel based on the principle of least privilege.
    • Vulnerability Management: Conduct regular security assessments, penetration testing, and code reviews to identify and address vulnerabilities.
    • Incident Response Plan: Develop a comprehensive incident response plan to detect, contain, and remediate security incidents promptly and effectively.
  3. Demo File and User Data Protection:
    • Consent for Sharing: Obtain explicit consent before sharing demo files or user data with third parties, such as esports teams or sponsors.
    • Anonymization and Pseudonymization: Implement techniques to anonymize or pseudonymize data whenever possible to reduce the risk of re-identification.
    • Secure Storage: Store sensitive data, including demo files, in secure environments with appropriate encryption and access controls.
    • Data Retention Policy: Establish a clear data retention policy, specifying the retention periods for different types of data and ensuring data is deleted or anonymized when no longer needed.
  4. User Authentication and Security:
    • Strong Authentication: Enforce strong password policies and consider implementing passwordless authentication options (e.g., biometrics, security keys).
    • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Enable MFA as an option or requirement for enhanced account security.

    • Ongoing Monitoring: Continuously monitor the security practices and compliance of third-party vendors.

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Strong Security Posture: User data is protected with industry-standard security measures, and the platform undergoes regular security audits.
  • User Trust: Users feel confident that their data is handled responsibly and securely.
  • Industry Recognition: LeetGraming.PRO is recognized as a leader in data privacy and security within the esports industry.

Technical Considerations:

  • Legal Expertise: Engage legal counsel with expertise in international data protection laws to ensure full compliance.
  • Privacy by Design: Embed privacy considerations into every stage of the development process.
  • Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs): Conduct DPIAs for high-risk processing activities.

item.title: [REPL-18] EPIC: Data Science and Machine Learning Initiatives
item.description:
Description:

Utilize advanced data science and machine learning techniques to unlock the full potential of the vast amount of data collected by LeetGraming.PRO, enhancing analysis, personalization, and overall user experience.

Goals:

  1. Advanced Statistical Modeling:
    • Develop sophisticated statistical models to analyze player and team performance trends.
    • Identify hidden patterns and correlations within the data that can provide deeper insights into gameplay.
    • Use statistical analysis to evaluate the effectiveness of different strategies and tactics.
    • Provide users with data-driven recommendations based on statistically significant findings.
  2. Predictive Modeling:
    • Build predictive models to forecast:
      • Match outcomes based on pre-game data (e.g., player stats, map history).
      • In-game events like round wins, clutch success, and individual player performance.
      • Future player and team rankings based on skill progression.
    • Use these models to provide users with probabilities and insights into potential outcomes.
  3. Recommendation Engine:
    • Develop a robust recommendation engine that suggests:
      • Personalized training plans and exercises based on individual weaknesses and strengths.
      • Relevant pro player demos and matches for study.
      • Optimal strategies and tactics for specific game scenarios.
    • Continuously refine the engine based on user feedback and engagement data to improve recommendation accuracy.
  4. Anomaly Detection:
    • Implement anomaly detection algorithms to identify unusual or suspicious gameplay patterns.
    • Detect potential cheating, scripting, or exploiting of game mechanics.
    • Alert moderators or administrators to investigate and take appropriate action.
    • Use anomaly detection to identify outliers in performance data for further analysis.
  5. Data Visualization and Exploration:
    • Create interactive dashboards and visualizations to empower users to explore their data.
    • Offer advanced filtering and segmentation options to isolate specific aspects of gameplay.
    • Provide tools for users to visualize their progress over time and compare their performance to others.
    • Enable the creation of custom reports and visualizations to meet specific user needs.

  • Enhanced Insights: The platform provides deeper and more actionable insights than competitors, thanks to advanced data analysis techniques.
  • Improved Personalization: Users receive highly relevant and personalized recommendations that accelerate their skill development.
  • Accurate Predictions: Predictive models provide reliable forecasts of match outcomes and individual player performance.
  • Fair Play: Anomaly detection helps maintain a fair and competitive environment by identifying and addressing suspicious behavior.
  • User Empowerment: Users have the tools and visualizations to explore and understand their data on their own terms.

Technical Considerations:

  • Data Infrastructure: Invest in scalable data storage and processing infrastructure to handle large volumes of data.
  • Machine Learning Tools and Libraries: Select appropriate ML frameworks (e.g., TensorFlow, PyTorch) and libraries (e.g., scikit-learn) for model development and deployment.

item.description:
Description:

Expand LeetGraming.PRO's global reach by implementing internationalization (i18n) and localization (l10n) features, enabling the platform to support multiple languages and cultural preferences.

Goals:

  1. Language Support:
    • Identify target languages based on market research and user demographics.
    • Prioritize languages with the largest potential user base and esports communities.
    • Implement support for the initial set of languages (e.g., English, Spanish, Chinese, Korean, Portuguese).

    • Establish a system for managing translations of all UI elements, content, and documentation.
    • Utilize professional translation services or leverage community contributions for translation efforts.
    • Implement a translation memory tool to ensure consistency and efficiency in translations.
    • Develop a process for reviewing and approving translations for quality assurance.
  3. Locale-Specific Formatting:
    • Adapt the platform to handle different number formats, date formats, currencies, and measurement units based on user locale.
    • Ensure correct display of times and time zones for matches and events in different regions.
    • Consider cultural nuances and adapt the UI design and content presentation accordingly.
  4. Content Localization:
    • Translate educational content (guides, tutorials, articles) into supported languages.
    • Adapt in-game terminology and jargon to match local preferences and understanding.
    • Consider localizing marketing materials and promotional campaigns for specific regions.
  5. User Interface Adaptation:
    • Design the UI to seamlessly switch between languages and adapt to different text directions (e.g., left-to-right, right-to-left).
    • Ensure that all UI elements, including menus, buttons, and forms, are translated correctly and displayed appropriately for each language.

  • Multilingual Support: The platform supports multiple languages with accurate and high-quality translations.
  • Locale Awareness: The platform correctly handles locale-specific formatting, including number, date, currency,and measurement units.
  • Cultural Adaptability: The UI design and content presentation are sensitive to cultural differences and preferences.
  • User Preference: Users can easily select their preferred language and locale within the platform.
  • Positive User Feedback: Users from different regions find the platform accessible and easy to use in their native language.

  • Internationalization Libraries: Utilize i18n libraries or frameworks (e.g., react-intl, i18next) to manage translations and locale-specific formatting.

    • Image Optimization: Compress images and utilize responsive image loading techniques.

    • Caching: Utilize browser caching for static assets.
    • Performance Profiling: Identify and address performance bottlenecks using browser profiling tools.
  2. Backend Performance Optimization:
    • Database Query Optimization: Optimize database queries for faster retrieval of data.
    • API Response Optimization: Minimize the size of API responses and utilize compression techniques.
    • Efficient Algorithms: Employ efficient algorithms for data processing and analysis.
    • Load Testing: Conduct regular load testing to simulate real-world usage and identify performance issues.
  3. Demo Processing Optimization:
    • Parallel Processing: Implement parallel processing for demo file parsing and analysis to reduce processing time.
    • Cloud-Based Processing: Utilize cloud resources for scalable and on-demand demo processing.
    • Prioritization: Prioritize demo processing based on user subscription levels or other criteria.
    • Feedback Mechanism: Provide users with real-time feedback on demo processing status and estimated completion time.
  4. Monitoring and Error Tracking:
    • Real-time Monitoring: Implement monitoring tools to track server performance, API response times, and error rates.
    • Error Tracking: Utilize error tracking services (e.g., Sentry, Rollbar) to capture and analyze errors in both frontend and backend.
    • Alerting: Set up alerts to notify the team of performance degradation or critical errors.
  5. Continuous Optimization:
    • Regular Audits: Conduct regular performance audits to identify areas for improvement.
    • Performance Budgeting: Set performance budgets for key metrics (e.g., page load time, API response time).
    • Iterative Improvements: Continuously iterate on code, infrastructure, and algorithms to maintain optimal performance as the platform grows.

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Fast Page Load Times: Ensure the landing page and other key pages load quickly.
  • Responsive Interface: The UI should be responsive and interactive, even under heavy load.
  • Efficient Demo Processing: Demo files should be processed and analyzed in a timely manner.
  • Minimal Errors: The platform should experience minimal errors and downtime.
  • User Satisfaction: Users should report a smooth and responsive experience on all devices and network conditions.

Technical Considerations:

  • Performance Profiling Tools: Utilize browser developer tools and backend profiling tools to identify bottlenecks.
  • Caching Solutions: Implement caching mechanisms like Redis or Memcached to improve response times.
  • Cloud Infrastructure: Consider using cloud providers (AWS, Azure, GCP) for scalable and on-demand resources.

item.title: [REPL-5] EPIC: Scalability and Performance
item.description:
Description:

Ensure the LeetGraming.PRO platform can handle a large number of concurrent users, process high volumes of demo data efficiently, and deliver analysis results with minimal latency.

Goals:

  1. Load Testing:
    • Conduct comprehensive load testing to simulate various user scenarios and traffic patterns.
    • Identify performance bottlenecks and areas for optimization under stress.
    • Establish baseline performance metrics (e.g., response times, throughput, resource utilization) and set performance goals.
  2. Database Optimization:
    • Design and implement a scalable database schema that can handle the increasing volume of demo files and analysis results.
    • Optimize database queries for faster data retrieval and reduce the load on the database server.
    • Employ indexing strategies and consider sharding (MongoDB) or partitioning (if together with Kafka) for large-scale datasets.
  3. Caching Strategies:
    • Implement caching mechanisms at multiple levels (e.g., in-memory, distributed caching) to improve response times and reduce the load on backend services.
    • Strategically cache frequently accessed data, such as player stats, match summaries, and visualization results.
    • Invalidate cache entries when data is updated to ensure consistency.
  4. Cloud Infrastructure:
    • Leverage cloud-based infrastructure (e.g., AWS, Azure, GCP) for scalability and flexibility.
    • Utilize auto-scaling to dynamically adjust resources based on demand.
    • Employ load balancing to distribute traffic across multiple servers for optimal performance.
    • Consider content delivery networks (CDNs) to speed up the delivery of static assets.

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Performance Under Load: The platform should maintain acceptable response times and throughput under heavy user loads.
  • Scalability: The platform should be able to handle increasing volumes of demo files and users without significant degradation in performance.
  • Efficient Data Processing: Demo file processing and analysis should be completed within a reasonable timeframe.
  • Optimal Resource Utilization: The platform should utilize server resources efficiently to minimize costs.
